author: @bjmaynard01
text: Not sure if I made a mistake somewhere or it's just the fact that these videos are a few years old, but to get the modal to pop up, I had to use data-bs-toggle="modal" and data-bs-target="#deleteModal". Then to get the modal to close I had to use data-bs-dismiss="modal". Might help someone else.

author: @urbaneplanner
text: I was running into issues with the modal that appears at 40:00 - it appears that since this video was created, the reference "data-toggle" in bootstrap has been revised to be "data-bs-toggle" - same with "data-target" - so the relevant code needs to be <button type ="button" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm m-1" data-bs-toggle="modal" data-bs-target="#deleteModal">Delete</button>. It works with this adjustment

author: @investandcyclecheap4890
text: For anyone having trouble not being able to delete a post. I found that using a button class instead of a input class worked. Here is the code:                                                                                                                           <form action = "{{url_for('delete_post', post_id = post.id )}}", method = "POST">                     <button class="btn btn-danger" type="'submit">Submit</button>

author: @julianalden-salter7697
text: Fantastic Tutorials.  I did have an issue with the modal not appearing but fixed it with: <button type="button" class="btn btn-danger btn-sm m-1" data-bs-toggle="modal" data-bs-target="#deleteModal">Delete</button> and <button type="button" class="btn btn-secondary" data-bs-dismiss="modal">Close</button>  Note the addition of '-bs' in data-bs-target, etc. In case anyone else is having this issue...

author: @hasangoni4369
text: I had a problem with the layout. My Account and login always stayed left side of the screen. Then I googled it and found the answer . The problem was bootstrap class update.  ml-auto => ms-auto mr-auto => me-auto Also note that data-toggle and data-target have changed too:  data-toggle => data-bs-toggle data-target => data-bs-target

author: @jacquestroussard9857
text: So I feel like when it comes to the modals, there are a lot of abstracted moving parts i.e. here is where a host of things can potentially go wrong. I followed the video and found that my delete button was unresponsive (modal would not open up) and it seems that the scripts sourced from the CDN can be a little tricky/fragile/out-of-alignment. I ended up trying many of the suggestions posted in the comments; debugging, browser js settings, etc. In the end I started trying swapping in different js CDN links and eventually got one that worked. I haven't regression tested the rest of the project but in case someone else is stuck on this part here is the set of links that worked for me:  <script src="https://code.jquery.com/jquery-3.2.1.slim.min.js" integrity="sha384-KJ3o2DKtIkvYIK3UENzmM7KCkRr/rE9/Qpg6aAZGJwFDMVNA/GpGFF93hXpG5KkN" crossorigin="anonymous"></script> 	<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/popper.js/1.12.9/umd/popper.min.js" integrity="sha384-ApNbgh9B+Y1QKtv3Rn7W3mgPxhU9K/ScQsAP7hUibX39j7fakFPskvXusvfa0b4Q" crossorigin="anonymous"></script> 	<script src="https://maxcdn.bootstrapcdn.com/bootstrap/4.0.0/js/bootstrap.min.js" integrity="sha384-JZR6Spejh4U02d8jOt6vLEHfe/JQGiRRSQQxSfFWpi1MquVdAyjUar5+76PVCmYl" crossorigin="anonymous"></script>  sourced from this bootstrap page (v4) https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/getting-started/introduction/#js  Be sure to replace the existing ones, doubling up here will be akin to dumpster fire of imports.

author: @Cytzix
text: Per Flask documentation (http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/1.0/patterns/wtforms/) the form.request argument is required when route method is POST which creates the form with the new generated data we have submitted. But in your tutorial you did not included this argument in your form and it still works. How so?

author: @1cannon3
text: (18:19) - How to create a route for specific blog posts  -- (18:30) - This is accomplished via passing variables to routes  -- (18:35) - Creating a route where specific post id is part of route  -- (18:47) - Corey creates the new route  -- (20:14) - get_or_404( ) method for db query  -- (20:58) - Creating a ‚Äúpost.html‚Äù template  -- (22:09) - Linking posts on home page to the actual post url/route  (25:31) Adding functionality to update and delete posts  -- (25:37) - Route for ‚Äúupdating a post‚Äù  -- (25:50) - Corey creates ‚Äúpost_id/update‚Äù route  -- (26:40) - Making sure the only use who can update post is the author  -- (26:53) - about(403), 403 HTTP restricted response  -- (29:45) - creating a ‚Äúlegend‚Äù value to reduce amount of HTML templates  -- (30:40) - updating the ‚Äúlegend‚Äù in ‚Äúcreate_post.html‚Äù  -- (30:52) - Populate the content for a post that you want to update  -- (31:34) - Logic for updating post if form validates (IOW current user is the author of post)  -- (33:40) - Putting the populate content code from 30:52 into a conditional for GET request    -- (35:35) - We can do this in the ‚Äúpost.html‚Äù template    -- (38:19) - Using a Bootstrap modal  44:00 Delete Post Route

author: @harryrobinson761
text: I really like how you do the tutorial iteratively so as to mirror the way development actually happens (sometimes). You'll write a few lines of code just to make sure something works and then remove it and then build it up a bit more and then retest. And you also only do imports just before you're about to code for them so we know exactly what they're for (unlike other tutorials where they'll just import everything and say we'll need it later).

author: @WolverineAndSloth
text: I've been trying to add a comment section for the blog posts, which I largely managed to do. I say "largely" because it now displays ALL comments for ALL posts under each and every post (so the comments are all the same). So I guess I need to put the comments and the blogposts in a relationship to one another, similarly to what we did with blog post and user id. I can do that by creating another db.relationship in our models.py. The problem is, however, that we used the flask_login import of current_user to associate blogposts with user_ids, but there is no such import for associating comments with blogpost_ids is there?  /e: figured it out. this reddit post helped: https://www.reddit.com/r/flask/comments/9boe36/trying_to_add_comments_to_a_flask_blog/

author: @nark9190
text: I‚Äôve got to say, I‚Äôm doing python for my gcse‚Äôs, I believe they‚Äôre called final exams in America, but this is extremely helpful for forums, final exam projects etc... once you learn these basics you know anything since websites are basically fully based around databases and basic functionality nowadays.  Edit: Like, if you notice a lot of repetition is used in websites, forms, design, forms, design, forms, design, and then the rest is just basic to intermediate functionalities.  I added a few extra functionalities after watching this video, such as dislikes and likes, and it‚Äôs ordered by likes-dislikes, so basically the popularity of the post, so say a post has 2 likes and 1 dislike and 1 post has 5 likes but 5 dislikes, the first one will be more popular because it has +1 instead of 0.
